content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Trent Piatkowski: I was born in Charlotte, North Carolina, and grew up in a pretty stable household. My parents were both educated—my dad had a graduate degree, and my mom had a bachelor's. They worked full-time, so we were never short on anything, though we weren't super wealthy. I remember my mom being really involved in our lives, always encouraging us to read and learn. My dad was more laid-back but always supported our education. I was raised as a Protestant, but I haven't been religious since I was a teenager. I went to college right after high school, got my bachelor's degree in something I wasn't super passionate about—maybe business or economics. I wasn't sure what I wanted to do, so I just went with what was safe. After college, I worked a few different part-time jobs, mostly in customer service or retail, and I've been doing that for a while now. I never really joined the military, and I've never married or had kids. I'm pretty independent, and I lean slightly liberal, though I don't follow politics too closely. I've moved around a bit since I was 16, but I still call Charlotte home. It's not the most exciting life, but it's been steady and comfortable.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Trent Piatkowski: Looking back, I think the crossroads came right after I graduated from college. I had this degree in business, but I wasn't really excited about it. I remember sitting in my dorm room, staring at my diploma, and feeling like I had checked a box but not really found my path. I had a few options: I could try to get a job in finance or consulting, which were the typical paths for someone with my degree. Or I could take a risk and try something different, like moving to a different city or even traveling for a while. I was 23 at the time, and I felt like I had this weird pressure to be 'successful' in a traditional sense. But I also felt like I was just going through the motions. In the end, I chose the safe route—got a part-time job at a local bookstore and started working in customer service. It wasn't what I had planned, but it gave me time to figure out what I really wanted. That decision taught me that sometimes the 'safe' choice isn't the wrong one—it just means you have more time to explore other options. I think that's why I ended up staying in Charlotte, because I didn't want to rush into something I wasn't sure about. It was a quiet moment, but it shaped a lot of my decisions after that.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Trent Piatkowski: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way most people might expect. I wasn't making a big, dramatic decision like moving across the country or quitting my job. It was more of a quiet realization that I didn't want to follow the script everyone else seemed to be following. I saw friends who went into finance or corporate jobs, and they were doing well, but I felt like I was watching their lives from the outside. I didn't want to be someone who just went through the motions. So I made the decision to take a step back, to not rush into something just because it was expected of me. It wasn't a sudden epiphany—it was more like a slow shift in how I saw myself and what I wanted. I think that's why I ended up staying in Charlotte, because I wanted to be close to home and have the freedom to explore without pressure. It wasn't a perfect decision, but it felt right at the time.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Trent Piatkowski: Looking back, I think my mom was the one who probably saw what I wasn't seeing at the time. She always encouraged me to think about what made me happy, not just what was practical. I remember one conversation we had after I graduated, where she said something like, 'You don't have to rush into the first thing that comes your way. Sometimes, taking a little time to breathe and figure things out is the best thing you can do.' It wasn't a big speech, but it stuck with me. I don't know if I would have made the choice I did without her nudging me in that direction. I think if I had had more support from people in my life—like a mentor or a counselor—it might have made the transition easier. But I also think I needed that time to be on my own to really understand what I wanted.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Trent Piatkowski: I don't have a partner or children right now. I've never really been in a long-term relationship, mostly because I've been focused on figuring out what I want for myself before committing to someone else. I do stay in touch with my parents, though—they're both still in Charlotte, and we have dinner together every now and then. My mom still reads a lot, and she's always encouraging me to keep learning, even if it's just through books or online courses. My dad retired a few years ago and now spends a lot of time gardening and volunteering at the local community center. I respect their values and the life they built, but I also want to carve out my own path. I think I'm content with where I am for now, even if it's not the most conventional life story.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of clarity to my own life story. It made me realize how much of my path has been shaped by choices I made out of comfort rather than passion, and how important it was to take that time to figure things out on my own. I think I've always been someone who values stability, but I also want to make sure I'm not just going through the motions. The questions made me reflect on how my parents influenced me, especially my mom, who always encouraged me to think about what made me happy. It's funny how the decisions I thought were just small, like staying in Charlotte or taking a part-time job, ended up defining so much of who I am today. I'm not sure if I would have had the same clarity without looking back on it like this, but it's given me a better understanding of myself and the life I've built.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Trent Piatkowski: I have an older sister, Sarah, who's a few years older than me. She went a different route—she moved to California after college and got into the tech industry. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's always interesting to hear about her life. She's more driven and ambitious than I am, which I admire. I think part of the reason we're not as close anymore is that we've made different choices, but I still respect her for going after what she wanted. She's married now, has a kid, and lives in San Francisco. I visit her every few years, and it's always a reminder of how different paths can lead to completely different lives. I don't think I would have made the same choices she did, but I'm glad she found her own way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Trent Piatkowski: I have a few close friends from college who I still keep in touch with, though we all ended up going different ways. One of them, Jake, is actually in the same part-time job I started with at the bookstore, and we still meet up for coffee sometimes. He's the one who introduced me to a lot of the indie authors and smaller publishers, which ended up sparking my interest in reading more deeply. I also have a couple of coworkers from my current job who I consider good friends—people I can talk to about everything from the latest books to just random thoughts about life. They don't have the same background as I do, which is interesting. One of them is from a different part of the country, and he's always telling me about his hometown and how it's shaped his views on things. It's funny how even in a small, part-time job, you can meet people who challenge you to think differently. I don't know if I'd call any of them family, but they're definitely important to me in their own way. They help remind me that life doesn't have to be about following a script—it can be about finding your own rhythm, even if it's not the one everyone else is on.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Trent Piatkowski: I live in a neighborhood called Oakwood, which is a bit on the quieter side of Charlotte. It's one of those places where you can walk to the local park, the coffee shop, and even the library without needing a car. The streets are lined with old oak trees, which is probably why it's called Oakwood, and there's a real sense of community here. A lot of the people who live here are either long-time residents or people like me who moved here for stability. There's a mix of professionals, retirees, and even some young people who are just starting out. I like that it's not too fast-paced or overly commercialized. My apartment is on the second floor of a small building with a few other units, and I actually enjoy the fact that it's not too big. It's just enough space for me, and I've managed to make it feel like home with a few bookshelves, some plants, and a small kitchen that I use for cooking simple meals. I've never really thought about moving again, mostly because I've come to appreciate the comfort of knowing where I am. There's a sense of familiarity here, and I think that's something I've always valued in my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Trent Piatkowski: I definitely feel safe here. It's not the kind of neighborhood where you have to worry about crime or strangers lurking around. There's a real sense of familiarity and trust among the neighbors. I've never had any issues with my apartment or the people around me. In fact, I've gotten to know a few of my neighbors over the years—some of them are regulars at the local coffee shop, and we've had some good conversations about everything from books to politics. It's not perfect, but there's something comforting about living somewhere where you don't have to lock your doors at night or second-guess your surroundings. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed here for so long—it's not just about the physical space, but the feeling of security and belonging that comes with it.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Trent Piatkowski: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of stability I mentioned before. I don't have to worry about the daily chaos of a bigger city, and I like knowing that I can walk to most places without feeling overwhelmed. The community here is pretty tight-knit, and I've actually gotten involved in a few local events, like the annual book fair at the library. It's a small thing, but it gives me a sense of purpose and connection. On the downside, I sometimes feel like I'm stuck in a routine. I work part-time, I read, I hang out with friends, and I go to dinner with my parents. It's comfortable, but I wonder if I'm missing out on something more. I've thought about taking a class or maybe even volunteering somewhere new, but I also don't want to disrupt the balance I've found. It's a bit of a paradox—feeling content but also curious about what else could be out there.

Going through the questions about my family, friends, and neighborhood made me realize how much my current life is shaped by the people and places I've chosen to stay close to. I've never been one for big changes or dramatic shifts, but looking back, I see how the decisions I made—like staying in Charlotte, keeping my part-time job, and staying in touch with my parents and a few close friends—have created a life that's steady and familiar. It's not the life I thought I'd have when I was younger, but it's the one I've built, and I've come to appreciate it. I think I'm content with the way things are, even if I sometimes wonder what could have been if I had taken a different path. Still, I feel lucky to have a neighborhood that feels like home and people who support me, even if they're not always the ones I expected.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Trent Piatkowski: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though there are a few variations depending on work and social plans. I usually wake up around 8 or 9 in the morning, have a slow breakfast—maybe some coffee and toast—and then head into work. My job at the bookstore is pretty flexible, so I might start around 10 or 11, depending on how I feel that day. I work a few hours, mostly helping with inventory, customer service, or just recommending books. After work, I like to take a walk around the neighborhood or grab a coffee at the local shop. On some days, I'll meet up with Jake or one of my coworkers for lunch or just to chat. Other days, I'll go home, read for a while, and maybe watch a movie or listen to some music. I try to set aside a couple of hours each evening to read, which has become a real comfort for me. On weekends, I might visit my parents for dinner, or if I'm feeling more adventurous, I'll go to a local event or just explore the city a bit. It's not the most exciting schedule, but it's steady, and I've come to appreciate the rhythm of it. There are days when I wonder if I should be doing more, but I also think there's value in the quiet, predictable life I've built.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Trent Piatkowski: I work part-time at a local bookstore called 'The Page Turner,' which is actually one of the reasons I've stayed in Charlotte. The job isn't glamorous, but it's flexible and gives me a chance to be around books, which I've always loved. I work every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, usually from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., though sometimes I'll stay a little later if there's a big event or if I need to catch up on inventory. The rest of the week is pretty open, which I appreciate because it gives me time to read, meet up with friends, or just relax. I've been there for a few years now, and I've actually gotten pretty close to some of the other staff. One of them, a guy named Marcus, is from Nigeria and has this amazing story about how he ended up in Charlotte. It's funny how a part-time job can sometimes feel like a second home, even if it's not the kind of job people usually talk about when they're bragging about their careers.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Trent Piatkowski: Outside of work and my regular routine, I also try to keep up with some personal projects, like writing short stories or journaling. It's something I started doing a few years ago as a way to process my thoughts and keep my creativity alive. I don't share them with anyone, really—I just write for myself. It's not like I'm trying to be a writer or anything, but it helps me feel more connected to who I am. I also have this habit of collecting old books or book covers that I find interesting. I keep them in a box under my bed, and sometimes I'll flip through them just to see what stories I've come across over the years. It's a small thing, but it gives me a sense of continuity, like I'm part of something bigger. I guess it's my way of finding meaning in the everyday, even if it's not the most traditional path.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Trent Piatkowski: Actually, there have been a few small changes lately. I started taking a short online course on creative writing a few weeks ago, just for fun. It's been a nice way to challenge myself without committing to anything too intense. I've also been trying to get more involved in the local library's book club, which meets every other week. It's a small group, mostly people from the neighborhood, and we read a variety of genres. I've found that it's been a good way to meet others who share my love for reading, even if it's not the same kind of social interaction I had in college. Another thing is that I've started going to the park more often, especially in the evenings. I used to just walk by it on my way home, but now I'll sit on one of the benches and read for a while. It's peaceful, and I think it's helped me feel more connected to the place I live. I don't know if these changes are huge, but they've made my days feel a little more intentional lately.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Trent Piatkowski: I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them. But I can imagine what it might be like if I did. I think I'd want them to have a balance between structure and freedom—maybe waking up early enough to have a good breakfast, going to school, and then having some time for creative activities or sports. I'd probably encourage them to read a lot, just like I did growing up, and I'd make sure they had time to explore their interests without too much pressure. I guess I'd also want them to feel comfortable asking questions and making their own choices, even if it means they don't always follow the same path I did. It's funny, isn't it? How something you never experience can still shape the way you think about it.

Going through the questions about my neighborhood, job, and daily routines made me realize how much comfort and familiarity shape my life. I've always been someone who values stability, and the way I've built my life—staying in Charlotte, working at the bookstore, and keeping a steady routine—has given me a sense of peace. But I also see that there's a quiet curiosity in me, a part of me that wonders if I'm missing out on something more. The recent changes I've made, like taking a writing class and joining the book club, are small steps toward exploring that curiosity without losing the comfort I've built. It's interesting how even in a life that feels predictable, there's still room for growth and discovery.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Trent Piatkowski: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major chronic conditions or serious illnesses, which I'm grateful for. I do try to stay active, mostly through walking around the neighborhood or taking the occasional bike ride when I feel like it. I've always been someone who values routine, so I try to eat fairly regularly—breakfast, lunch, and dinner, even if it's just a quick meal. I'm not the biggest fan of exercise in the traditional sense, like going to the gym or lifting weights, but I do enjoy being outdoors. I think the biggest thing that affects my health is stress, though I don't always recognize it until it's there. I've been trying to be more mindful about it lately, especially with the small changes I've made in my routine, like joining the book club and taking that writing class. It's funny how something as simple as reading in the park or discussing books with others can make a difference in how I feel overall. I guess I'm not someone who thinks about health in a dramatic way, but I do appreciate the little things that keep me feeling steady and grounded.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Trent Piatkowski: I think what makes it easy to stay healthy is the routine I've built around walking and reading. There's something about being outside, even just for a short walk, that helps me feel grounded. It's not about pushing myself to be in perfect shape—it's more about staying active in a way that doesn't feel like a chore. On the flip side, what makes it harder is when I get too caught up in my own head, especially when I'm reading or writing. I can lose track of time and forget to eat properly or take breaks. I've noticed that when I'm too focused on one thing, like a book or a project, I tend to neglect other parts of my health. But I've been trying to remind myself that balance isn't about perfection—it's about showing up for yourself, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Trent Piatkowski: Actually, there hasn't been anything major in the past two years related to my health. I've been pretty consistent with my routine, and I haven't had any serious issues. The only thing that comes to mind is that I did have a minor back strain a few months ago from lifting a heavy box at work. It wasn't anything serious—it just reminded me that I need to be more careful with my posture, especially when I'm doing things like organizing shelves or moving books. I took it easy for a few days, stretched a bit more, and it went away. It wasn't a big deal, but it did make me think about how even small things can affect your body if you're not paying attention. I guess that's why I've been trying to be more mindful of how I move and how I take care of myself, even in the little ways.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Trent Piatkowski: Honestly, I don't think my health has ever really gotten in the way of anything major in my life. The back strain I had a few months ago was more of a minor inconvenience than anything else—it didn't stop me from working or doing the things I needed to do. I think part of that is because I've never been someone who pushes myself too hard or takes on too much at once. I've always leaned into the idea of pacing myself, which I guess has helped me avoid some of the bigger health issues that other people might face. That said, I know there are people out there who deal with chronic conditions or serious illnesses that completely change their lives, and I respect how hard that must be. For me, it's more about staying aware of my body and making small adjustments when needed, rather than dealing with anything that would really disrupt my routine.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Trent Piatkowski: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of contentment and quiet curiosity. There's something comforting about the rhythm of my life—waking up, working at the bookstore, reading, and seeing my parents for dinner. It's steady, and I think that's what I've come to value most. But there's also this undercurrent of wondering if I'm settling for something less than what I could be. I've been trying to push myself a little more, like with the writing class and the book club, and it's been nice to feel like I'm growing in small ways. I don't know if I'm any closer to figuring out what I really want, but I do feel like I'm more aware of the choices I'm making. It's not dramatic or life-changing, but it's something. I think I'm learning that growth doesn't always have to be loud—it can be quiet, and it can happen in the everyday things you do, like reading a book or writing a few sentences just for yourself.

Going through the recent interview questions about my daily routines, health, and small changes in my life made me realize how much of my identity is tied to the comfort of routine and the quiet moments I've built for myself. I've always thought of my life as steady and predictable, but looking back, I see how even the smallest shifts—like taking a writing class or joining a book club—can spark a sense of growth without disrupting the balance I've found. It's interesting how health, for me, isn't about dramatic changes or strict regimens, but about being mindful of the little things that keep me grounded. I've come to appreciate that staying healthy isn't about perfection, but about showing up for myself in small, consistent ways. I also see how my health hasn't really been a barrier in my life, which I think is partly because I've never pushed myself too hard or ignored my body's signals. It's a reminder that sometimes, the most important things in life aren't the big, flashy changes, but the quiet, intentional choices we make every day.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Trent Piatkowski: I don't think I've ever really struggled with depression or anxiety in the way that some people do. I've had moments of feeling stuck or unsure about my direction, especially after college, but I've always found ways to push through them. I think part of that is because I've never been someone who dwells too much on the negative. I've always tried to focus on the things that bring me comfort—like reading, walking in the neighborhood, or just having a quiet evening with a book. That said, I've noticed that there are days when I feel more distant from everything, like I'm just going through the motions. But I don't think it's anything that's held me back in a major way. I've always had a pretty good sense of self, and I think that's helped me stay grounded even when I'm not sure where I'm headed. I guess I'm not someone who needs a lot of external validation or support to feel okay—I've always found peace in the small, steady things in life.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Trent Piatkowski: For my family, things have been pretty stable too. My parents are both in their late 60s now, and they've settled into a rhythm that works for them. My mom still reads a lot, and she's always encouraging me to keep learning, even if it's just through books or online courses. My dad retired a few years ago and now spends a lot of time gardening and volunteering at the local community center. I respect their values and the life they built, but I also want to carve out my own path. I think I'm content with where I am for now, even if it's not the most conventional life story. They've always been supportive of my choices, even when I've taken the slower road. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in Charlotte and not feel like I'm missing out on something bigger. They've given me the freedom to figure things out on my own, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Trent Piatkowski: I was raised as a Protestant, but I haven't been religious since I was a teenager. Looking back, I think it was more about the structure and community that church provided than any deep spiritual belief. As I got older, I started to question a lot of the things I was taught, and I found myself more interested in the ideas and philosophies that came from books and conversations than from sermons or scripture. I still respect the values my parents instilled in me through their faith, like kindness and hard work, but I don't think I need organized religion to feel connected to something bigger. For me, spirituality is more about the quiet moments—like sitting in the park reading, or reflecting on a story that really moves me. It's not something I think about every day, but I do believe that there's value in being mindful of the world around you and the people in it. I guess I'm more of a person who finds meaning in the small, everyday things rather than in any formal belief system.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Trent Piatkowski: I don't use social media much, to be honest. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or even just the quiet of a book over scrolling through my phone. I have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and a few old friends, but I don't post much or engage with the content too often. I've noticed that the more I use it, the more it feels like it takes away from the time I could be reading or talking to someone in person. I think it's funny how people can get so caught up in their online lives, but for me, it's just not the same as real connection. I do follow a few book-related pages or authors I admire, but I don't feel the need to be constantly updated on what's happening in the digital world. It's not that I'm anti-social media—it's just that I've found my own way of staying connected, and it doesn't involve screens very much.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Trent Piatkowski: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support, even during tough times. I've always found comfort in the people I know in real life—my parents, my friends, or even just the quiet moments I have with a book. I think part of it is that I've never been someone who opens up a lot online. There's something about putting your thoughts out there for strangers to see that feels a little too exposed for me. I've had moments where I've felt stuck or unsure about my direction, but I've always found ways to work through them on my own or with the people I trust. I guess I just don't see the point in looking for validation or support from people I don't really know. It's not that I'm against it—I just prefer the kind of connection that comes from actually talking to someone face-to-face, or even just sitting in silence with someone who understands without needing to say anything.

Going through the recent interview questions about my health and feelings over the past year made me realize how much of my well-being is tied to the small, consistent choices I make every day. I've always thought of myself as someone who values stability, and it's true—I don't seek out big changes or dramatic shifts. But I've also come to understand that growth doesn't have to be loud or overwhelming. It can happen in the quiet moments, like taking a writing class, joining a book club, or simply being more mindful of how I move my body. I've always been someone who leans into the comfort of routine, and I think that's why I've managed to stay healthy and grounded without needing to push myself too hard. I also see now that my feelings of contentment are real, but they're mixed with a quiet curiosity about what else could be out there. I don't know if I'll ever take a big leap, but I'm learning that it's okay to keep exploring in small ways, even if I never leave the path I've built.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Trent Piatkowski: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually been pretty low, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've been more intentional about the small changes I've made—like joining the book club, taking that writing class, and spending more time in the park. These things don't eliminate stress entirely, but they do give me a sense of purpose and connection that I hadn't really considered before. When I do feel a little overwhelmed, I tend to fall back on the same coping strategies I've always used: reading, walking, or just sitting with a cup of coffee and letting my thoughts settle. I've also started journaling more, which has been a helpful way to process things without overthinking. I think the biggest shift for me has been realizing that I don't need to be constantly striving for something bigger to feel fulfilled. It's not about eliminating worry or stress—it's about learning how to move through it without letting it take over. I've come to accept that some days I'll feel more curious about what else could be out there, and other days I'll just be content with where I am. And that's okay.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Trent Piatkowski: In terms of making ends meet, my monthly budget is pretty straightforward. I live frugally, which has always been a part of my personality. My biggest expenses are rent, groceries, and utilities. Rent for my apartment is around $1,200 a month, which is manageable since I don't have any other major debts or obligations. Groceries are another big one—especially since I like to cook at home, which I think is healthier and more satisfying than eating out all the time. I also try to buy in bulk or take advantage of sales when I can. Utilities are a bit variable depending on the season, but I've always been careful about not wasting electricity or water. I also set aside a small amount each month for books and other personal interests, which is something I've always valued. I don't have a lot of discretionary spending, but I do make sure I have enough for the things that matter to me—like reading, staying connected with my family, and having a little bit of time for myself. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to live comfortably without feeling stretched too thin. I think part of why I've been able to manage financially is because I've never had a lot of debt, and I've always been careful with what I spend. It's not about luxury for me—it's about stability, and I think that's something I've always prioritized.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Trent Piatkowski: My household spending last month was pretty much in line with what I usually spend. I'd say it came out to around $2,500 total, give or take a few hundred dollars depending on how much I bought in groceries or if I had to replace anything small around the apartment. Rent is the biggest chunk—$1,200—then groceries, which usually run me about $600 to $700 a month. I try to be pretty careful with that, buying in bulk when I can and sticking to what I know I'll use. Utilities are another $150 to $200, and I also set aside about $100 for books and other personal interests, like the writing class I'm taking. The rest goes toward things like coffee, a few meals out with friends, and some small expenses here and there. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover everything I need without feeling like I'm constantly stretching. I think the key for me has always been living within my means and not getting caught up in things that don't really matter. It's not about being poor—it's about knowing what's important and making sure I have enough of that.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Trent Piatkowski: We rent our home. I've never really considered buying a house, mostly because I've always valued the flexibility that renting gives me. I don't see myself staying in Charlotte forever, though I've come to really appreciate the stability it offers now. Renting also means I don't have to worry about maintenance or property taxes, which I think is a relief for someone who doesn't have a lot of extra money to spare. My apartment is small, but it's all I need. It's not about the size—it's about the sense of control I have over my space. I can move things around, decorate it however I want, and not have to worry about long-term commitments. I think that's why I've never felt the need to own a home—it just doesn't fit with the way I like to live, which is more about simplicity and ease than about building something permanent.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Trent Piatkowski: Over the past year, my bills have stayed pretty consistent, which I think is partly because I've always been careful with my spending. Rent is the same every month, and I've never had any issues with that. Groceries do fluctuate a bit depending on the season—like, I tend to spend a little more in the winter when I'm cooking more at home and less in the summer when I'm eating out with friends more often. Utilities also vary a little, especially in the summer when the air conditioning kicks in and the electricity bill goes up. But I've always been mindful of turning things off when I'm not using them, so it's never been too bad. The biggest change I've noticed is that I've started spending a little more on books and the writing class I'm taking, which is something I didn't budget for at first. It's been a small but meaningful addition to my routine, and I've made sure to adjust my other expenses to make room for it. Overall, I think the fluctuations have been minor, and I've been able to manage them without any real stress. It's just another part of the steady life I've built, and I've come to accept that some things will change a little, while others stay the same.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much of my life is shaped by the people I care about and the ways I choose to stay connected—with family, with my community, and even with myself. It's interesting how my family's stability and support have been a constant in my life, even as I've chosen a quieter, more independent path. I've always valued the quiet moments, like reading or walking in the park, and I think that's why I don't feel the need to rely on social media or online validation. I've come to realize that my sense of well-being comes from the small, consistent choices I make every day—like staying in touch with my parents, reading, or even just sitting with my thoughts. I'm not someone who needs a lot of external noise or validation to feel grounded. It's the simple, real connections that matter most to me, and I'm grateful for the life I've built, even if it's not the one I thought I'd have when I was younger.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Trent Piatkowski: I do have a savings account, though it's not anything extravagant. I've always believed in setting aside a little bit each month, even if it's just a small amount, to have some financial cushion. I usually put around $100 to $150 into my savings every month after paying my rent, groceries, and utilities. It's not about getting rich or anything like that—it's more about having a sense of security, just in case something unexpected comes up. I've never had a lot of money, so I've learned to be careful with what I do have. I also try to avoid debt as much as possible, which is why I don't use credit cards or take out loans for things I can't afford. I think the key for me has always been consistency. It's not about saving a lot at once, but about making sure I'm saving a little every month, even if it's just for the peace of mind it gives me. I know it's not the same as what some people do, but for me, it's enough to feel like I'm taking care of myself without being too strict or stressful about it.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Trent Piatkowski: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing rather than big purchases like a home. I've never really thought about buying a house, mostly because I don't see myself staying in one place for too long. But I do like having that little cushion, just in case something unexpected comes up. I've had moments where I've had to cover small repairs or unexpected expenses, and it's been reassuring to know I had a little something set aside. I don't save a lot, but I think it's enough to give me peace of mind. It's not about being prepared for the worst—it's more about knowing that I'm not completely caught off guard if life throws me a curveball. I've always believed in small, consistent actions, and saving a little each month is just another way of showing up for myself, even if it's not in a dramatic or flashy way.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Trent Piatkowski: My occupation has always been pretty straightforward—I work part-time at 'The Page Turner,' which is a local bookstore in Charlotte. The job isn't glamorous, but it's something I've come to really appreciate. My main duties involve helping customers find books, managing inventory, and sometimes organizing events like author readings or book clubs. I also spend a fair amount of time recommending books to people, which is one of the things I enjoy most about the job. It's interesting because I've always loved reading, and being around books every day has kept that passion alive. I think the most important part of the job for me is the sense of connection it gives me—whether it's with customers who find a book that changes their perspective or with the other staff members who have become like family over the years. It's not the kind of job that's going to make me rich or famous, but it's given me a sense of purpose and a way to stay grounded in the things I care about. I don't think I would have found that kind of fulfillment in a more traditional career, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Trent Piatkowski: I usually work around 12 to 15 hours a week, depending on the season and how busy the store gets. It's a flexible schedule, which I really appreciate because it gives me the freedom to balance work with my other interests—like reading, writing, or just spending time with my parents. Some weeks I might work a little more if there's an event or if I need to cover for someone, but on average, it's pretty light. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay in Charlotte for so long—having that part-time job gives me enough income to live comfortably without feeling like I'm tied down to a full-time schedule. It's not the kind of job that defines my life, but it's definitely a part of it, and I've come to value the stability it brings.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Trent Piatkowski: I've had a few other part-time jobs over the years, especially right after college when I was still figuring things out. I worked at a coffee shop for a while, which was pretty similar to the bookstore in that it involved a lot of customer interaction and a pretty laid-back environment. I also did some freelance work online, mostly editing or proofreading for small businesses or individuals who needed help with their content. It wasn't steady or long-term, but it gave me a little extra income and helped me stay connected to the kind of work I enjoy—writing, reading, and helping others with their words. I think what I've come to realize is that I don't need a single job to define me or my life. Having a few different roles, even if they're part-time or short-lived, has helped me stay flexible and open to new experiences. It's not about having a traditional career path—it's about finding what works for me and being okay with the fact that it might not look like what other people expect.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much of my well-being and sense of stability come from the small, consistent choices I make every day. I've always valued the quiet rhythm of my life—working part-time, reading, spending time with my parents, and staying connected with a few close friends. It's not about grand gestures or dramatic changes, but about finding peace in the everyday things that bring me comfort. I've come to realize that my emotional coping strategies, like reading or walking in the park, are deeply tied to the sense of grounding I've built over the years. I also see now that my financial habits, though simple, are a reflection of the same values: living within my means, prioritizing what truly matters, and not getting caught up in things that don't add value to my life. It's interesting how these small, steady choices have shaped my sense of contentment, even if I sometimes wonder what else could be out there. But I think I've learned that it's okay to be where I am, as long as I'm still growing in the ways that feel right for me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Trent Piatkowski: In terms of income, my household makes around $2,000 to $2,200 a month from my part-time job at the bookstore. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, and other essentials without too much strain. I don't have any other sources of income right now, but I've always been okay with that. I think part of it is that I've never been someone who needs a lot to feel content. I've always valued stability over extravagance, and I've come to appreciate the life I've built without needing more. It's not about not wanting more—it's more about knowing what I need and being satisfied with that. I've also been careful with my spending, which has helped me avoid debt and keep things manageable. I don't know if I'll ever have a higher income, but I don't think I need it to be happy. It's the small things—the books I read, the walks I take, the time I spend with my parents—that make me feel like I'm living a full life, even if it's not the one everyone else is chasing.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Trent Piatkowski: I've been at 'The Page Turner' for about five years now, which feels like a long time when you think about how quickly life can change. The benefits of the job aren't the typical ones you hear about in corporate jobs—there's no health insurance or paid vacation days, but there are other things that make it worth it. For one, the flexibility is huge. I can choose my days off based on what I need, which is something I really appreciate. The store also has a great culture—everyone there is passionate about books, and that makes the work feel less like a job and more like being part of a community. We support each other, whether it's helping out during busy seasons or just sharing a good book recommendation. I've also gotten to know a lot of regular customers who have become like friends over the years. They come in with stories, questions, and sometimes even life updates, which makes the job feel more meaningful than I ever expected. It's not perfect, but I think the intangible benefits—the connection, the sense of purpose, and the freedom to live on my own terms—make all the difference.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Trent Piatkowski: My relationships at work are pretty good, actually. I've been lucky to have a manager who's more of a mentor than a boss. Her name is Linda, and she's been at the bookstore for over 20 years. She's the kind of person who knows everyone by name and has a story for every book on the shelves. She gives me a lot of freedom, which I really appreciate, and she's always been supportive of my small projects, like the writing class I took or the book club I started. As for my coworkers, we've all become pretty close over the years. We joke around, we help each other out, and we've even had some pretty deep conversations about life, books, and what we're looking for in our own paths. It's not a traditional office environment, but there's a real sense of camaraderie and mutual respect. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed here for so long—it's not just about the job, but about the people I've come to care about along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Trent Piatkowski: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's also flexible in a way that suits my lifestyle. I usually work the same days each week—Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays—but I can adjust my hours a bit depending on how I'm feeling or if there's something else I need to do. The store manager, Linda, is pretty understanding, so if I need to leave a little early or come in a bit late, she doesn't bat an eye. That flexibility is something I really value because it gives me the freedom to maintain my routine—like reading in the evenings or spending time with my parents on the weekends. I think that's why I've stayed in Charlotte and kept this job for so long. It's not about having a rigid schedule or being tied down to a nine-to-five. It's about having a job that fits into the life I've built, not the other way around.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Trent Piatkowski: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, and I know there are people out there who have it much better than I do, but I also know that I've never had to worry about the basics. I can afford to rent a place that feels like home, I can buy groceries without stress, and I can still spend time on the things that matter to me—like reading, writing, or just sitting in the park with a book. I think part of what makes me feel good about it is that I've never been someone who chased money for the sake of it. I've always believed that stability is more important than status, and I think that's why I've been able to find peace in the life I've built. I know there are days when I wonder what could have been if I had taken a different path, but I also know that I've made choices that have given me a life that's steady, predictable, and, in its own way, fulfilling. I don't think I need more than what I have right now to feel like I'm living a full life.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much of my life is built on consistency and small, intentional choices. I've always valued stability, and it's clear that my financial habits, work schedule, and even my savings reflect that. I don't chase big changes or dramatic shifts, but I've found peace in the predictability of my life—working part-time, managing my expenses carefully, and saving a little each month. It's not about being rich or having the most exciting job, but about knowing that I can cover my needs without stress. I've also come to appreciate the flexibility my job offers, which allows me to maintain the rhythm I've built around reading, walking, and staying connected with the people I care about. It's interesting how these small, steady choices have shaped my sense of contentment, even if I sometimes wonder what else could be out there. But I think I've learned that it's okay to be where I am, as long as I'm still growing in the ways that feel right for me.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Trent Piatkowski: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom worked as a teacher for over 20 years, and my dad was a researcher in a university lab. They both had pretty stable jobs, which gave our family a sense of security. I remember my mom always being busy grading papers or planning lessons, but she made sure to set aside time for us—like reading with me before bed or taking us to the library on the weekends. My dad was more of a quiet presence, but he was always supportive of my education. He even helped me with my math homework sometimes, even though he wasn't a math teacher. I think their work ethic really shaped me, especially my mom's dedication to teaching. She always said that education was the key to opportunities, and I think that's why I ended up going to college right after high school. I don't know if I would have had the same drive without seeing them work so hard and value learning so much. It's funny how the things they did—like staying up late to grade papers or working late nights in the lab—became part of the background of my life, but they definitely left an impression on me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Trent Piatkowski: My mom was a high school English teacher, and her most important activities revolved around lesson planning, grading papers, and connecting with her students. She had a way of making literature feel alive, and I remember how she would bring in stories from her own life to help us understand the ones we were reading. She also ran a small book club for teachers in the district, which I think is where she developed her love for discussing ideas and stories with others. My dad, on the other hand, worked as a research scientist at a university, mostly in the field of environmental studies. His most important duties involved conducting experiments, analyzing data, and publishing papers. He was pretty quiet about his work, but I remember him coming home with stories about the projects he was working on—like how he was studying the impact of climate change on local ecosystems. Both of them had different kinds of work, but they shared a common value: they believed in the power of knowledge and the importance of doing meaningful work, even if it wasn't always glamorous. I think that's why I ended up valuing education and the quiet, steady life I've built for myself—because I saw how their work shaped not just their lives, but also the lives of the people around them.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Trent Piatkowski: My mom worked for the Charlotte Public Schools system, and my dad was employed by a university in the state—probably UNC Charlotte, though I'm not entirely sure. My mom's job was pretty much centered around teaching and mentoring students, and she made sure that her work had a real impact on the lives of the kids she taught. She wasn't just there to give grades; she was there to help them think critically, to challenge them, and to show them that reading and writing could be powerful tools. My dad's work was more behind the scenes, but it was just as important. He was part of a research team that studied environmental changes and their effects on local wildlife. I remember him coming home with maps and data charts, and I used to think he was just doing math all day. But looking back, I realize how much of a difference his work must have made in understanding the world around us. Both of them worked for organizations that valued knowledge and service, and I think that's why I ended up valuing those things too. It wasn't just about the money they made—it was about the work they did and the way they approached it with care and dedication.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Trent Piatkowski: I hope that in a few years, I'm still living in Charlotte, still working at the bookstore, and still finding joy in the small things—like reading a good book, walking in the park, or having dinner with my parents. I don't know if I'll ever take a big leap or change my path completely, but I hope I'm still growing in the ways that feel right for me. I'd like to keep writing, maybe even publish a few stories or essays somewhere, but I don't want it to be about pressure or expectation. I hope I'm still content with the life I've built, even if it's not the one I thought I'd have when I was younger. I also hope that I'm still connected to the people who matter most—my family, my friends, and the community I've come to love. I think the most important thing for me is that I'm still being true to myself, even if that means staying in the same place, doing the same things, and finding meaning in the quiet, steady rhythm of everyday life.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Trent Piatkowski: What I value the most in my life is the sense of stability and connection that comes from the simple, everyday things. I value the quiet moments—like sitting with a book in the park, having a meaningful conversation with my parents, or even just knowing that I can walk to the store or the library without worrying about anything. I value the freedom to live on my own terms, without the pressure of chasing something bigger or more exciting. I also value the people I've built relationships with, whether it's my family, my coworkers, or the few friends I still keep in touch with. They've all played a role in shaping who I am, even if I didn't always realize it at the time. And I value the fact that I've been able to build a life that feels like mine, even if it's not the one I thought I'd have when I was younger. It's not about perfection or grand achievements—it's about finding meaning in the small, steady things that make life feel real and full.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial situation shape the rhythm of my life. I've always valued the stability that comes with my part-time job at the bookstore, and it's clear that this job has given me more than just income—it's given me a sense of purpose, connection, and freedom to live on my own terms. I've come to appreciate the flexibility of my schedule, the supportive relationships I've built with my coworkers and manager, and the fact that I don't have to chase a traditional career path to feel fulfilled. It's also made me think about how my financial situation, while modest, has allowed me to live comfortably without the stress of debt or extravagant spending. I've learned that contentment doesn't come from having more—it comes from knowing what you need and being satisfied with the life you've built, even if it's not the one others might expect.

Going through this complete interview and life story has given me a deeper understanding of the path I've taken and the choices that have shaped who I am. I've always thought of my life as steady and predictable, but looking back, I see how even the smallest decisions—like staying in Charlotte, working at the bookstore, or taking a writing class—have built the life I now live. It's not the life I thought I'd have when I was younger, but it's the one I've built, and I've come to appreciate it. I've realized that growth doesn't always have to be dramatic or life-changing; it can happen in the quiet, everyday moments. I've also come to understand how much my parents' values and the people I've surrounded myself with have influenced me, even if I didn't always recognize it at the time. This reflection has reminded me that I don't need to chase a different path to feel fulfilled. I'm content with where I am, and I'm grateful for the life I've built—one that is steady, meaningful, and filled with the things that bring me comfort and joy.
